Legal_Issue: Whether the Visa Officer acted arbitrarily or breached procedural fairness in denying the request for substituted evaluation under subsection 76(3) of the Regulations
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, subsection 76(3)
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant fell short of required points, provided insufficient evidence of work experience, did not meet key requirements
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate error or unfairness
Credibility_Factor: Officerâ€™s decision based on credible evidence
Legal_Rule: Visa Officers have discretion under subsection 76(3) to conduct substituted evaluations if unusual facts exist or the applicant nearly meets selection criteria
Grounds_for_Claim: Arbitrary decision, lack of procedural fairness
Outcome_on_Merits: Officer's decision was not arbitrary or capricious
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: No breach of procedural fairness found
Key_Evidence_Considered: Work experience documentation, points assessment, eligibility criteria
Legal_Framework: Canadian immigration law, administrative law principles
Applicant_Challenge: Denial of substituted evaluation under skilled worker class
Legal_Rule_Source: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Standard_of_Proof: Balance of probabilities (applicant level), patent unreasonableness (review level)
Defendant_Response: Decision made within discretionary authority and based on evidence
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, application forms, supporting documents
Remedy_Sought: Substituted evaluation and approval of immigration application
Legal_Provision: Subsection 76(3) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Failure to meet selection criteria, insufficient work experience proof
Governing_Rule: Subsection 76(3) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
